Agency: Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority
Event Description: On Saturday, October 3, {Redacted} {Redacted}:24, Metro {Redacted} {Redacted} Train {Redacted}, traveling southbound on track # {Redacted}, collided with a motorist. The motorist was traveling westbound on {Redacted} street. At the time of the incident, {Redacted} grade crossing did not provide the minimum 20 seconds of advance warning time. The signaling system perceived there to be a ghost train occupying the same track circuit, which caused the gates to clear, and the power anomaly failed to recognize the approaching train that collided with the motorist. The signaling system lost power for approximately 13 seconds due to a power anomaly, which then failed to deploy the traffic gates for the train involved in the collision.   The {Redacted} ad {Redacted} were subsequently notified of the failure. Just prior to the collision, the signaling system detected a malfunction in its system, and removed the speed code from the incident train on three consecutive occasions. However, instead of notifying control and requesting authorization to change operating modes, the train operator took it upon himself to put the train back into service by placing the train in " street - running " mode, which is a violation of our safety rules. By doing this he bypassed " stop and proceed " mode, which is the safest mode of travel. Also, a post incident investigation revealed that all the components involved in the signaling power system, passed their integrity tests, including the back - up batteries.   However, as an additional safety precaution, both the charger and batteries were replaced in order to rule out any possibility of a similar occurrence. The weather was clear and dry.   There were no glares on the windshield that could have affected the operatorÂ¿s visibility of the crossing.   Upon noticing the vehicle, the operator sounded the loud horn and went into emergency baking but could not stop the train in time to avoid the collision.   The driver if the vehicle and a child were transported to a local hospital for observation only.
Rail Alignment: Non-exclusive right-of-way: Shared with vehicles or pedestrians
Person List: I    Occ Other Veh Adult (19 to 60) M ; I    Occ Other Veh Adult (19 to 60) F

Upon noticing the bicyclisttrespasser, the train operator sounded the loud horn and applied emergency braking but could not stop the train in time to avoid the collision.   The bicyclisttrespasser suffered unknow but non - life - threatening injuries.   He was transported by Paramedics to a local hospital.   Two passengers on the train claimed injuries. Agency: Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority
Event Description:
Our investigation revealed that on November 6, 2020, at approximately 2:35 pm, car # {Redacted} train number was assigned ) traveling eastbound from {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} to {Redacted} Track 4 derailed while making a trailing point move through {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} Yard. The switch was not lined for the intended route and as the car derailed through the switch point the middle, â C â, truck came off the rails. This section of track is located on a curve as well as then incident switch. As a result of the derailment the switch point indicator ( {Redacted} ) was damaged and the concrete ties suffered minor abrasions as a result of wheel contact. There were no injuries reported as a result of the slow - speed derailment. 

 The {Redacted} {Redacted} Yard is in pre - revenue service and as a result has a number of punch list items to complete before revenue operation. Due to signal work being conducted in the yard, many of the switches in the yard have been placed into the hand - throw position and fuses removed. These switches, including switch 21, are noted in the Yard {Redacted} {Redacted}. 

 Per the Operator âs statement, the switch point indicator light was dark due to the switch being out of motor and in the hand - throw position. 

 Per the {Redacted} âs report, during the time leading up to the derailment, the operator was instructed by the Yard {Redacted} to stop and read back all switch points before proceeding. The operator failed to read back the switch she derailed over. 

 The train operator was taken for a drug and alcohol test as per procedure. 

 Multiple attempts were made to retrieve the car âs video system footage of the incident; however, it was discovered that this car was still undergoing acceptance testing and had not been officially accepted by Metro. As a result, the car did not have a functional video system and no video or audio from the car was captured. Nevertheless, similar to the rest of the fleet, the affected train will have a functioning video system compliant with {Redacted} {Redacted}
Approximate Address: Crenshaw Yard - 5740 Arbor Vitae, Los Angeles
Rail Alignment: Exclusive right-of_way: sidings / rail yard / other non-revenue track

Agency: Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority
Event Description:
On November {Redacted}, 2020, Metro {Redacted} {Redacted} Train # {Redacted} was traveling Southbound on Track # {Redacted} when it collided with a commercial tractor - trailer fouling the track at {Redacted} grade crossing. The train made contact with the right rear of the commercial tractor - trailer and the commercial driver fled the scene, â hit and run. â The {Redacted} {Redacted} and {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} responded to the scene. No injuries were claimed as a result of the collision. Lead Car # {Redacted} sustained damage to the side mirror. The operator was not taken for a drug and alcohol test per procedures. 

 {Redacted} crossing is a four - track, 2 - quadrant gated crossing consisting of flashers, bells, cantilevers, and gate arms. The two outer tracks are operated by {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} ( {Redacted} ), while Metro operates on the two inner tracks. 

 {Redacted} {Redacted} and CPUC representative {Redacted} reviewed the accident video footage. The video revealed the operator sounded his loud horn and initiated emergency braking. The bells and gates were activated. The moments leading up to the collision there were no personal electronic devices observed in use by the operator, and he appeared alert and attentive. 

 A post - incident {Redacted} {Redacted} report found that the active and passive warning devices at the grade crossing were operating as intended. {Redacted} was notified of the collision.
Rail Alignment: Non-exclusive right-of-way: Shared with vehicles or pedestrians

Agency: Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority
Event Description:
{Redacted} {Redacted}'s investigation revealed that on February 23, 2021, at approximately 1138 hours, Train # {Redacted} traveled northbound with a two- car consist and collided with a trespasser. The leading car was # {Redacted}, followed by # {Redacted}. Per the Train Operator âs report, a pedestrian had physically run onto the tracks and positioned himself down in front of the train. Video evidence has verified this account.   The Train operator informed the {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} that the train had collided with a pedestrian. 

 {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted}, along with the {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted}, arrived at the scene. Per {Redacted} report the trespasser was taken to {Redacted} in critical condition. {Redacted} received the police report, which stated that the pedestrian strike was an attempted suicide. 

  {Redacted} {Redacted} personnel conducted an inspection of the crossing and determined that the crossing was functioning as designed.   There was no reported wayside damage. 

 Representatives from the {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} ( {Redacted} ) and Metro {Redacted} {Redacted} {Redacted} reviewed all available accident video footage. The in - cab video revealed that in the moments leading up to the collision, the operator appeared to be alert and attentive; furthermore, no personal electronic devices were observed being used while the operator was operating the train. The gates, bells, and flashers were active while the trespasser was running towards the train. Video also verifies that the Train operator used the proper horn sequence while approaching the crossing and applied emergency braking.
